body.p: EsiGate fully implements ESI 1.0 Language Specification 1.0 and adds also a few extra (but useful) features. Here is the reference list of all supported tags, attributes and variable expressions.

section.name: <esi:include>
section.p: This tag specifies to include some part of another web page. Here is basic example:
This tag has several other attributes that enable to have a precise control on what you want to retrieve from the page, transform, cache, handle errors... See the reference table bellow for details.

section.name: <esi:replace>
section.p: This tag can be used only nested inside an include tag and is used to specifies things to replace inside the included fragment.
This tag has several other attributes that enable to have a precise control on what you want to retrieve from the page, transform, cache, handle errors... See the reference table bellow for details.

section.name: <esi:fragment>
section.p: Delimits a fragment inside a page. This fragment could be fetched or retrieved by another page.

section.name: <esi:try> <esi:attempt> <esi:except>
section.p: Enables to handle http errors like 404 or 500.

section.name: <esi:inline>
section.p:
Defines fragments that will be stored separately in the cache in order to be reused later. See ESI 1.0 Language Specification 1.0
for details.

section.name: <esi:comment>
section.p: A comment that appears in the source code of the page but will be removed after ESI processing.
section.source: <esi:comment text="This comment will not be sent to the client" />

section.name: <esi:remove>
section.p: Almost like comment tag. The html nested inside remove tag will be visible inside the page before processing but will be removed by the processing. This tag is very useful for example when you are using a page as a template and you want to see it with sample contents when it has not been ESI-processed.
section.source: This is a sample text that will be removed

section.name: <!--esi -->
section.p: Exactly the opposite of remove tag. Before ESI processing the content of the tag will be seen by the browser as an html comment but after inclusion the tag itself will be removed and the content will become visible.

section.name: <esi:vars>
section.p: Some variable expressions can be used inside esi tag attribute values. With this tag you can use expressions anywhere in your page, you just have to put a vars tag around the part of the page that may contain expressions.
section.source: <esi:vars> The user-agent of your browser is: $(HTTP_USER_AGENT) </esi:vars>

Note: the expression "PROVIDER" is a specific EsiGate expression useful to externalize the base Url of provider applications inside the configuration file. All the other expressions supported by EsiGate are the ones defined inside the specification.
